contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. They will emphasize to Pharaoh what will happen if Pharaoh does this. Alternate translation: "if you continue refusing to let them go" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: if you refuse to let them go, if you still keep them back

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the month in which the events of this chapter take place will be the beginning of their calendar year. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For you, this month will be the start of months, the first month of the year to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are two different types of physical reminders so people will not forget something important. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: This will be a reminder for you on your hand, and a reminder on your forehead

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expresses two ways to remember the importance of the passover event. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Exodus 13:9](./09.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: become a reminder on your hands, and a reminder on your forehead

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and are used for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: an enemy to your enemies and an adversary to your adversaries

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. The second explains how the tablets were "God's own work." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The tablets were God's own work, and the writing was God's own writing
